text: Some awesome responses here, thanks everyone! I agree with all of you. I think it depends on the topic: if you can answer the question in 2,000+ words, then go ahead. If not, then don't force it!

text: What is a good article that explains why educational/SEO content should focus on educating & fixing your customer's problem, rather than selling your solution at every second paragraph?

elements.text: What is a good article that explains why educational/SEO content should focus on educating & fixing your customer's problem, rather than selling your solution at every second paragraph?

text:
YES! You're talking about levels of product/solution awareness. In fact, most content should just EMPATHIZE with them and then send them to another article that can more deeply help them solve the problem.

Link: <https://seofortherestofus.org/seo/search-intent/>

elements.text:
YES! You're talking about levels of product/solution awareness. In fact, most content should just EMPATHIZE with them and then send them to another article that can more deeply help them solve the problem.

Link:

text:
That said "SEO" content should address every level of awareness. People are Googling at every level so we want to make sure we show up over and over throughout the buyer journey (or customer lifecycle, whatever you want to call it).

People stuffing product sales stuff into articles where people aren't even aware of their problems is... problematic.

There's even a level above all of this called "unaware" where people aren't even aware what their problems are, so to push a solution on them is just silly.

elements.text:
That said "SEO" content should address every level of awareness. People are Googling at every level so we want to make sure we show up over and over throughout the buyer journey (or customer lifecycle, whatever you want to call it).

People stuffing product sales stuff into articles where people aren't even aware of their problems is... problematic.

There's even a level above all of this called "unaware" where people aren't even aware what their problems are, so to push a solution on them is just silly.

text: Yesss I completely agree with that. I'm trying to convince someone else that selling the solution at every section is problematic. I just can't find the words to explain why (apart from "it's too salesy")

elements.text: Yesss I completely agree with that. I'm trying to convince someone else that selling the solution at every section is problematic. I just can't find the words to explain why (apart from "it's too salesy")

text: What happens when you write an article that tries to satisfy several user intents at once? (since people don't go through a funnel in the typical pyramid way, it's mostly all over the place)

elements.text: What happens when you write an article that tries to satisfy several user intents at once? (since people don't go through a funnel in the typical pyramid way, it's mostly all over the place)

text: I wouldn't make the articles serve separate intent. From an SEO perspective, we want to match the level of awareness they have when they're searching for that term. Here's a B2C example:

elements.text: I wouldn't make the articles serve separate intent. From an SEO perspective, we want to match the level of awareness they have when they're searching for that term. Here's a B2C example:

text: and when people do this wrong, they think that one article should rank for "back pain" and convince somebody to try yoga, then sell them on the program with testimonials and reviews all on one page.

elements.text: and when people do this wrong, they think that one article should rank for "back pain" and convince somebody to try yoga, then sell them on the program with testimonials and reviews all on one page.

text: I agree, however with some keywords it's not so obvious. "online ordering systems" is one: the reader clearly knows what an online ordering system and they're looking for the best one. Does that mean you wouldn't include a "advantage of online ordering systems" section in your article?

elements.text: I agree, however with some keywords it's not so obvious. "online ordering systems" is one: the reader clearly knows what an online ordering system and they're looking for the best one. Does that mean you wouldn't include a "advantage of online ordering systems" section in your article?

text: Correct. I would not generically list the advantages of having one. I would re-write that section to include the advantages of having a GOOD one and how that framework is used to evaluate other solutions in the article itself.

text: Great list <@U01KT0GQ0UA> - thanks for sharing! I'm also a huge fan of giving attention to our content that is creating long-lasting engagement and conversions. Keeping content that is converting well up-to-date and relevant to our audience has always served me in my roles well!

text: It's a longish read, but I wrote something that might help, explaining to my audience (freelance software engineers, who are prone to "marketing by attrition as to why logic dictates you buy their solution") the problem with this approach.  I called it "troll under the bridge marketing," because you're basically leaping out at people minding their own business and accosting them with an unwelcome message: <https://daedtech.com/marketing-101-marketing-isnt-what-you-think-it-is-freelancers/>

elements.text: It's a longish read, but I wrote something that might help, explaining to my audience (freelance software engineers, who are prone to "marketing by attrition as to why logic dictates you buy their solution") the problem with this approach.  I called it "troll under the bridge marketing," because you're basically leaping out at people minding their own business and accosting them with an unwelcome message:

text: I drove home the point by adding an imaginary commercial into the post and then essentially asking them if their wallets were out, or if maybe, just maybe, they weren't in the mood to buy stuff when they clicked on the article and started reading

elements.text: I drove home the point by adding an imaginary commercial into the post and then essentially asking them if their wallets were out, or if maybe, just maybe, they weren't in the mood to buy stuff when they clicked on the article and started reading

text: If you wanted to live dangerously with client optics, the next time you're having that discussion, start trying to convince them to buy bitcoin or something, and then said, "oh, is that not why you called this meeting?" :smile:

text: One thing I think doesn't get talked about enough with content refreshes is optimizing the piece's conversion to whatever "next step" is best. I can usually double or triple the conversions during a refresh but it's not something other people seem to spend much time on?

elements.text: One thing I think doesn't get talked about enough with content refreshes is optimizing the piece's conversion to whatever "next step" is best. I can usually double or triple the conversions during a refresh but it's not something other people seem to spend much time on?

text: Just here to say thanks for this. We use a similar process. I filter average position of pages in GSC up to pos. 30 (so, up to pages 2 and 3). I select a few pages, look at which queries are driving a disproportionate impressions-to-clicks ratio (CTR). Then if it makes sense, choose a keyword to optimize the post for, which entails basically everything you laid out.

elements.text: Just here to say thanks for this. We use a similar process. I filter average position of pages in GSC up to pos. 30 (so, up to pages 2 and 3).
